Posts.Content: Nov 11, 2015 11:55AM anxiouslywaiting wrote: So sorry I haven't responded to you all. I've been trying to stay away until my 6-month follow up. Thank you so much for being so supportive and amazing. This is a great community. As far as my anxiety goes, I'm doing much better. I've been in intense therapy for the past six months in order to get my health anxiety under control. Unfortunately, I had my six month scans yesterday and now the radiologist wants to do a biopsy. She kind of confused me though. She wrote that I am a BIRADS 4A, which I expected, but that she thinks I'm "totally fine." She asked if I have b.c in my family, I said no (not that that matters a great deal to me. I'm well aware people still get breast cancer with no family history). So, I went back to my surgeon and she had the biopsy scheduled for Thursday. I ended up canceling it so I can get a second opinion. She told me the microcalcs are so scattered that she can't just do the biopsy when I'm awake; that I'll have to go under and she'll have to perform surgery to get them all. But, if they're that spread out, I thought that was, potentially, a good thing? She said that she thinks I'm fine and that I'm "being followed" and that's why they're being so extensive because they want to take every measure to risk not being sued. I did some research and she has a malpractice suit against her (patient ended up dying).. so, I'm having my records sent to another surgeon for a second opinion. My mom thinks (I'm 26...and when it comes to stuff like this, I turn into a small child again ha. She's been very helpful) they're being SO thorough because of my anxiety. Anyway, if this new doc says this is the only way to biopsy my calcs, then I'll do it...but if a doc can do it without putting me under, I'd rather go that route. I had surgery a year ago and would rather not go under anesthesia so soon. I don't know. This whole thing has just been really confusing. She said we can either do the biopsy, or get scans every 6months for 2yrs to make sure I'm fine(but she said that, bc of my age, they'd probably just end up doing a biopsy at the end of the 2yrs anyway). If she's saying I can wait another six months for scans, I figure I can wait a week and try to get squeezed in with another doctor for a potentially easier biopsy. I was SO quick to get a second opinion about my mammo, so I feel it's best to get a second opinion regarding a full surgery too. Every scan, magnified mammo, ultrasound, breast exam has come back "clean" aside from the microcalcs. No masses or anything. I am trying to not get ahead of myself as, I've learned, for my mental illness, it's best to just...take it day by day. I have yet to decide what I'll do if the biopsy doesn't come back B9. I just keep telling myself that, with Birads4, there's a 70% chance I'll be just fine. If I'm not, a majority of the "bad" microcalcs are either ADH or DCIS...trying not to think it's invasive just yet. It's...very frustrating to say the least. I haven't done much googling, as that negatively affects my health anxiety. Any advice regarding biopsies is more than welcome though. I'm not sure what to ask the next doc other than, "Do I have to be put under?" I just don't understand why they can't just numb it locally. The surgeon did explain that it's because she could get SOME but not ALL and just because one is b9, it doesn't mean they all are. But, again, why can't this happen when I'm awake? People stay awake for surgeries all of the time. What was supposed to be just a biopsy, turned into me having to go to pre-op to get a chest X-ray, cbc drawn, mammogram, something placed inside of my boob so the surgeon knows where to go, then an hour-long surgery followed by another mammogram. ...which is where I get ALL kinds of confused because they keep telling me, "I think this is nothing, but it's protocol." This seems a bit excessive for "nothing."

Posts.Content: Nov 24, 2015 12:10PM anxiouslywaiting wrote: After talking with some loved ones (I have to make this decision within the next few hours which is aggravating because my surgery is scheduled for next week), I think I'm going to do the less invasive biopsy. Both biopsies (needle and surgical) require 6month follow up scans. I know myself and I know my anxiety. Even IF they get every last microcalc out of there and they're all benign, I will be scared sh*tless come May. My peace of mind from removing all of them will not last long, because I have anxiety and that's, unfortunately, how it works ("What if something new popped up?!"). With that being the case, I'd like to be able to keep the sensation in my nipple (last surgeon said I'd lose some if I went through with the surgery) and be as non-invasive as possible until I absolutely need to go under the knife. Another thing that kind of helped make my decision was looking back on what my last surgeon said. She gave me two options: a surgical biopsy or watching every 6months for two years. I feel like those are extremes on opposite ends of the spectrum. This other surgeon said if I'd like to do a biopsy, I could push for one, but she would also not fight me if I'd rather wait another six months (bc at that point, it will have been one year since my calcifications were originally scanned with no change). A needle biopsy seems to be the best decision. I called John's Hopkins for another opinion a while ago and they recommended a needle biopsy instead of surgical. I guess I'll check back in with ya'll when I get the biopsy results.

Posts.Content: Nov 13, 2015 08:26PM anxiouslywaiting wrote: Djabi53, As far as bilateral calcs, I've heard that is good. I believe that is an indicator of simply aging breasts. When I had to wait these past six months (we did the watch and wait first. Now, she just wants to biopsy, unfortunately), I just really tried to focus on the "now." It really helped my anxiety. I completely understand when you say this this waiting period made you a different person. It has made me a completely different person. However, I think that part of it has been for the better. When you're petrified of what will happen in six months, you really try to savor every single day. The good thing about getting checked out every six months is that, I think, the worry almost decreases a bit. It's not, "Oh no...I have to wait another year, 10 months, etc., to find out if something is growing in there." It's just, "Okay. I have 6,5,4,3,2 months to go. I can do this. Until then, I'm going to enjoy right now because, even if I'm as healthy as a horse, I'll never get right now back." Do I wish I could simply be a carefree 26yo woman, yes, but life has other plans for me apparently. I'd listen to your docs. I have some unconcerning calcifications in my R breast actually, and I'm not having those biopsied. I'll likely be on a watch and wait for those. As for the other breast, I'm about 95% sure I'm going through with the surgery. The *only* thing keeping me back right now is my fear of how my loved ones will react. They don't want me to do it until I get a second opinion. However, I spoke to my radiologist again today and had her sit down and tell me everything about my scans. Literally everything. She was probably very frustrated ha. I trust her judgement completely. She's been doing this for such a long time. Back in March, for my first mammo, I believe I was something like her 71,111th patient. She comes highly recommended from every single person I've talked to. If she thinks this is the ONLY way to get them all, then I trust her. Unfortunately, they're all different shapes and sizes, which I know isn't ideal. She said it looks like someone took a rock and shattered it inside my breast and that the stereotactic will not be able to get every single one, and she wants them all taken out. After hearing that they're different shapes and sizes, and knowing what that means (no bueno), I can't imagine only having *some* taken out. If they come back benign (fingers.freaking.crossed), I won't be upset I did it because I'll know 100%. If they come back malignant, I would have had to have the surgery anyway to get the rest out. Right now, I just hope my family can respect my decision and support me (and not get frustrated when I get super bitter sometimes about how other girls my age are traveling the world, drinking wine, and simply being in their 20s).

Posts.Content: Dec 16, 2015 10:42AM anxiouslywaiting wrote: Wanted to update this thread as well: Had my biopsy yesterday. It was not nearly as bad as I thought I was going to be. I was sitting up the whole time, which was great. The women tending to me were incredible. Sore today and some bruising, obviously, but it's the same kind of "sore" I feel after a normal mammogram. It basically felt like getting a VERY fast tattoo. After the numbing meds, honestly, the most uncomfortable thing about it was that my leg was falling asleep (can't complain if that's the most uncomfortable part haha). It was a LITTLE confusing (in a good way) because the two radiologists didn't even want to do the biopsy (So, I've had one radiologist and surgeon say that I 100% NEED a full lumpectomy. I had the most recent surgeon say, she'd prefer to wait but will do the biopsy for peace of mind and I have her two radiologists telling me that this is basically ridiculous. My mind was all over the place). I told them my last doctor told me that it looked like a rock was smashed in my breast with all of the calcifications. The two radiologists, mammogram tech, and the nurse were all very angry with my previous radiologist. They showed me the scans. They were like, "these are SO faint that we can barely see them and are in no distinguishable pattern at all." The radiologist said the only reason I'm even at the biopsy point is because another doctor suggested it and I went through nine months of stress and anxiety, so they simply can't turn me away now. She did say if I'd rather not do the biopsy, she'd be 100% okay with it because she said she's almost positive that this is benign and that she hates it when doctors put the fear of God into girls in their 20s. I told her I wish I would have gone to her first, however, considering it's already been nine months, I don't think I can do another six months of waiting. I'd rather just know. Anyway, they said I should have my results on Friday at the latest. I took a Xanax the second I got into the room (which helped greatly. If any biopsy newbies are reading this and do suffer from anxiety, I really recommend it. It made it so much easier). I did end up having someone drive me: My FIANCÉ!! (I got engaged last Thursday). Hopefully, Friday's results will be a wonderful engagement present. Fingers crossed for B9 results and thank ya'll so much for your advice! I'll keep you guys posted.
